Award.AwardTitle: Special Project - Developing Virtual Content for STEM Career and Technical Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
Students enrolled in advanced technology education programs need to develop industry relevant hands-on skills and competencies to be considered for entry level jobs as skilled technicians. Thus, technical education must serve all students, including those who are working or caregiving and those who have transportation or other limitations to learning on campus. In addition, technical education must also serve high schools and colleges that cannot afford the expensive hands-on equipment needed for this training. This project will develop Augmented Virtual Reality content for three different STEM Career and Technical Education programs. It is expected that these resources will enable students to learn hands-on skills from any location with adequate internet access. These resources are also expected to have benefits beyond broadening access to education. It has been demonstrated that students who use AVR can learn to do a task more than twice as fast as students who use only traditional methods. This increased pace of learning is particularly noted for STEM tasks. Thus, the AVR resources developed by this project may also be used to improve the learning outcomes of in-person learners.

The Eastern Iowa Community College Augmented and Virtual Reality (AVR) Department has experience in developing applications that use AVR technologies to enhance traditional pedagogical practices in college and workforce education. The AVR program is both an education program for postsecondary students interested in learning how to use AVR technologies and an internal software development unit in which developers work on College-commissioned AVR projects. This project will bring together students and college AVR experts to work with business and industry subject matter experts to develop approximately thirty AVR modules for STEM-related career and technical education programs in Automotive Technology, Diesel Technology, and Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning Technology. The completed AVR modules will be used by students via Oculus Quest headsets. Project evaluation activities will assess the impact of the AVR modules on student learning outcomes, including the development of hands-on skills. The outcomes of students learning through AVR will be compared to those learning in person. The AVR modules will be available without charge on the College website and disseminated in STEM-related career and technical education fields so that high school and community college students across the country can achieve authentic hands-on learning remotely. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a pioneering effort to redefine technical education, a recent project has successfully integrated Augmented and Virtual Reality (AVR) content into STEM Career and Technical Education (CTE) programs, particularly in Automotive Technology and HVAC. Designed for desktop consumption using WebGL technology, this initiative was aimed at overcoming the traditional challenges of technical education by offering immersive, hands-on training experiences remotely.
The intellectual merit of this project is rooted in its innovative approach to teaching complex technical subjects. By embedding AVR modules into the curriculum, it has transformed the educational experience in Automotive and HVAC systems. These modules, offering interactive and immersive learning experiences, have simplified complex technical concepts, enhancing students' understanding and engagement. Critically, they align with national industry standards, ensuring the skills taught are relevant and up-to-date, addressing the skilled labor shortage and preparing students for real-world applications. Moreover, this project represents a substantial contribution to educational technology, setting new benchmarks for delivering complex technical skills and fostering innovation in teaching methodologies.
Beyond its educational impact, the project has profound societal implications. It democratizes education by making high-quality technical training accessible to a broader audience, including those in remote or under-resourced areas, enhancing educational equity and inclusivity. Furthermore, equipping students with industry-relevant skills positively impacts employment opportunities and contributes to economic growth. The project also encourages interest in STEM among younger generations, promoting a diverse and innovative future workforce. Additionally, it highlights the importance of lifelong learning and adaptability, essential skills in today's rapidly changing world.
The outcomes and achievements of this project are significant. Interactive AVR modules developed for Automotive Technology and HVAC have revolutionized these fields of study. Students are now able to virtually interact with various systems, gaining a deeper understanding and honing their problem-solving skills. This technological shift has reduced the need for extensive physical training resources, leading to cost savings and more efficient use of space. Additionally, the project necessitated upgrades in IT infrastructure, strengthening the technological capabilities of educational institutions. It also provided professional development opportunities for educators, equipping them with advanced teaching tools and preparing them for the evolving landscape of digital education.
In conclusion, the integration of AVR into STEM CTE programs marks a major advancement in technical education. It addresses the challenges of remote learning and sets a new standard for practical, accessible, and industry-aligned education. The success of these modules showcases the transformative potential of technologies like WebGL in education and skill development. More than its impact on science and technology, the project contributes significantly to societal progress. It fosters educational equity, drives economic growth, and cultivates a culture of innovation and practical problem-solving. This project is not just a leap forward in educational methodologies but also serves as a blueprint for future advancements, where technology and education merge to create a more skilled, adaptable, and inclusive society.
